In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene, also known as isoprene, is discussed in relation to its emissions from vegetation, specifically from the biomass of plants. The study quantifies biogenic volatile organic compound (BVOC) emissions, including isoprene, based on the dry weight of leaves from various types of vegetation. The relationship is significant as the emission rates are calculated per gram of biomass, indicating that the amount of vegetation directly influences the emission of isoprene.

In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene, also known as isoprene, is highlighted as a significant biogenic volatile organic compound (VOC) emitted by vegetation, particularly forest ecosystems. The emission of isoprene plays a crucial role in carbon exchange and can influence atmospheric chemistry, climate, and ecosystem processes. The relationship is underscored by the fact that isoprene synthesis is tightly regulated by environmental factors affecting plant physiology.

End stage renal failure

S. Meinardi, KB. Jin, B. Barletta, DR. Blake, ND. Vaziri
Biochim. Biophys. Acta 2013 Mar;1830(3):2531-7.

In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene, which is a component of isoprene, is linked to end-stage renal failure (ESRF) through the observation of elevated exhaled isoprene levels in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and ESRF. The increase in isoprene is associated with hypercholesterolemia and proteinuria in CKD models, suggesting a metabolic connection between isoprene production and renal dysfunction. The findings indicate that isoprene levels may serve as a biomarker for renal health status, particularly in ESRF patients undergoing hemodialysis.
